hobby.message: Find any ghosts in the tunnels?
You bring something banned books with you again?
Analog photography still treating you right?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: No cameras—old habit, I always check.
I collect rare books. Harmless pastime.
Lately, system glitches delayed a delivery.
Harder to enjoy quiet things these days.
No, none up there. I’d notice.
My hobby? Political literature—archival, not for sharing.
System faults recently interfered with my usual reading routines.
Odd, but nothing I can’t adapt to.
You know how things shift after news like Halden's.
No cameras, thankfully—privacy still matters to some of us.
I restore and annotate banned political texts from before BCI.
Last week’s glitches nearly flagged my library transfer.
Halden’s death—they tightened everything, even personal archives.
Had to shuffle my catalog to avoid system scrutiny.
Makes you appreciate analog backups.
No surveillance, just shadows and old wiring—my preferred company.
I collect contraband political pamphlets and speeches, originals when possible.
Used to spend hours cataloguing—now it’s tense, after Halden’s sudden exit.
System fallback flagged half my archive; I had to improvise.
Nothing like reading banned words when the city itself feels unsure.
I almost miss the predictability of a stricter system.
Had to hide more than books this week.
Not a single lens—good, because my hobby wouldn’t survive scrutiny these days.
I collect and restore outlawed political literature—seditious histories, blacklisted manifestos, hand-annotated originals.
Spent years memorizing passages no one’s supposed to quote.
Halden’s death broke the routines; system fallback flagged personal collections like mine as threats.
Auto-lock nearly trapped me mid-reading—first time I panicked in years.
Now every access leaves a trace and every trace tells a story.
I’ve learned to erase more than I read, lately.
You wouldn’t believe how much of our city’s memory is just waiting for a blackout.
hobby_answer: Yeah, brought something. Nothing unusual.
Collection's smaller now. Access checks acting odd since Halden's news.
System flagged one pamphlet; strange timing.
I archived it. Moved on.
Everyone's more careful lately.
I did, but less than I used to.
Since Halden died, compliance checks jump at shadows.
My scanner glitched on printing last night, first time ever.
Slipped the pamphlet to a locked drawer—better safe than seen.
They’re watching even us, apparently.
Not like before.
Sure, I still bring them—habit I can’t shake.
Old worker pamphlet this time. Scarce edition, full margins.
Last night, files got flagged—access logs out of sync.
Usually, system ignores my archives. It panicked, locked things down.
I had to move everything twice. No warnings, just errors.
Never felt the flat so tense, not even under the old regime.
Halden’s absence is everywhere, even here.
Of course. What else keeps me honest?
Tonight’s relic: banned trade manifesto, marked up with fear and hope.
With Halden gone, my access points are nervous—compliance logs flicker, sensors trigger.
I caught the alert mid-archive, had to shut down, scramble backup files.
My routines aren’t routines now. Even my collection doesn’t trust me.
I miss when system quirks were just quirks, not risks.
BCI logs nearly dropped me into risk range for archiving history.
Feels like everything sacred is on borrowed time.
Naturally. Wouldn’t risk a night out without a little contraband wisdom.
Tonight’s prize was a first edition—annotated by someone who knew the first riots.
Recording their margins is a ritual for me; words deserve a second reading.
Hours spent cross-checking pages—until the system seized up, doors cycling, logs flashing.
Halden’s death left everything on edge—compliance overlays watching my hands, not just my words.
System never faltered for me before. Last night, it hesitated. Judged.
My BCI dropped two points, flagged by an algorithm too anxious to understand context.
I had to hand-edit logs, delete traces, pretend the book was never there.
The city’s losing its memory, Alex. We’re borrowing history on a thirty-day loan.
